subject: Re: Conditionally running tests
msgSnippet: My issue is with DBUnit. It is definitely JUnit 3.8 test extension, so every time you make a class, you could forget to setup the setup method or the teardown
messageBody:
My issue is with DBUnit. It is definitely JUnit 3.8 test extension, so
every time you make a class, you could forget to setup the setup
method or the teardown method (that last one is a bigger deal, as
often the tests have no reason to recreate their own teardown, but
teardown puts the database back into a production state
(re-instituting the audit trail and other trigger-based operations,
for example). So in other words it would be an ongoing overhead every
time a new DBUnit test is made.

On the other hand, if the tester did make their DBUnit test class a
JUnit 4 class, it would work with this hack.

There are techniques for using DBUnit without subclassing its class
and kind of forcing testers to use JUnit4, but there is a lot of
common setup code that seems to be good in the setup method. In fact,
it seems a small step backwards that there is no way to inherit setup
and teardown from a superclass (or some other method, say an
annotation that runs the before and after declared in another class)
